captions.text: [ENGINES REVVING]

A little earlier in the year, we
proved, quite conclusively

at Santa Pod, that from rest
to about 130 miles an hour,

the new Ducati Panigale is
faster than a Porsche GT-2 RS.

For many people that
wasn't a surprise.

But the margin of its victory
surprised me and made me feel

a bit patriotic towards
the motorcar.

And I suspected that at really
high speed, the car might come
good again.

So here we are at
Bruntingthorpe, a two-mile
Second World War runway.

And I've got another Panigale
next to me, this time an S,

which is down a couple
of horsepower on
the Tricolore model.

Still Ben Cope from Visordown,
who spent most of his time on

the way here on the back wheel,
which I have to say is
quite cool.

We've got a bit more
space this time.

So we'll start again
from scratch.

And let's see what
happens when we
start to go a bit quicker.
[ENGINES REVVING]
He's just disappeared.
He has just disappeared.

Look, there's no other
way of putting it.

From a standing start,
even above 120,
the Porsche got murdered.

Even if I could have used
everything in first, it

wouldn't have made
any difference.

More worryingly, above 120
miles an hour the gap was
still widening.

We're going to do a rolling
start this time, because it's

a little bit fairer on the car
and because I don't want to
wreck the gearbox.

So rolling in second gear,
what's quicker?

And this time, we won't
stop at 130.

I think we'll just go, what I
hope every girl when I was 15
would say as, all the way.
[ENGINES REVVING]
He's on the back wheel.
[? Fair play. ?]
And he has disappeared.
Can we claw him back?

Because I'm doing 140 and
he's still going.

[BLEEP], that's quick,
that thing.

154, he's getting
away from me.

164, I've gotta get
my gear changed.
I'm still catching him.

194, 196, now we're
catching him.
Now we're catching him.

So in the end, we
can catch him.

Above 160, the GT-2
RS is a monster.
It just keeps pulling.

But the bike was so far ahead
by the time it hit an

indicated 180, I had to do an
indicated 202 to get past him.
But get past him, I did.
Eventually.

Now as the upholder of the motor
car's dignity in this

test, it was a pretty
tough day.

The bike was just astoundingly
fast.

Every time Ben twisted the
throttle, it opened a gap.

But I suppose we should be
impressed that a 911 can get

anywhere near a 195-horsepower
motorcycle.
[ENGINES REVVING]

title: 200mph Drag Race: Porsche GT2 RS v. Ducati 1199 Panigale - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: l

comments.text:
It's Aerodynamics. Motorcycles have the drag profile of brick. The Porsche, 
even though it has a bigger frontal area than the bike, it has a lower 
Coefficient of Drag (CD). The more streamlined car has more horsepower than 
the bike to push it though the air faster above 180mph. If the Panigale had 
the Termignoni race exhaust with its just 10hp more,and 10 lbs less weight, 
like the bike in the earlier test, the Porsche probably would not have 
caught it. This base Panigale cost just $19,000. USD﻿
comments.author: Jim Gianatsis

comments.text:
Nah, motorcycle has a Cd of about 0.5 to 0.7 depending on make and model. 
Brick is about 1.0 The net drag is the frontal profile in square meters x 
Cd  Air density is included in the equation. The speed is a function of the 
net drag and the horse power. Yes, you have pretty much written that but in 
a practical sense the top speeds of vehicles is irrelevant because of speed 
limits in nearly all countries and lack of suitable roads to drive at over 
150 mph. In most cases on the roads that I drive and ride, my bike is long 
gone at any practical speed.
comments.author: droceretik

comments.author: Wiggysan Wiggysan

comments.text:
+FreemaN1338 Perhaps but I have not seen the evidence yet. Maybe someone 
has done it but until we all see the GPS or timing data then it's an 
unanswered question. From the mile competition sites such as Texas Mile and 
following the links to competitor sites, it looks like 230 hp (crank) is 
required for a modded superbike with a stock chassis and aero. The Kawasaki 
stock HP2 looks like it has the credentials but it depends on the 
conditions and stock gearing. MotoGP bikes routinely hit 210 mph and they 
have a little over 240 hp but a smaller frontal area and jockey sized 
riders.
comments.author: droceretik

comments.text: +droceretik  Wouldn't the H2R be able to do 200mph+ ?
comments.author: FreemaN1338

comments.text:
Prove it with evidence, ie. gps data, video evidence, references. The 
record for a production motorcycle is 312 kph or 193 mph by an MV Augusta. 
It used to be quoted that the 1999 Suzuki Hayabusa was tested at 317 kph 
(196 mph). If you could be bothered, go to the Texas Mile site and look at 
stock motorcycle speeds over a standing mile. None are over 200 mph and 
usually in the high 180's and low 190's. It takes a lot of mods with a 
normally aspirated bike to get to 210 mph. These include derestriction, 
exhaust, gearing, chip, blueprinted engines, porting etc. It's not just a 
matter of taking the limiter off.

comments.text:
+LAUNCH CONTROL 東瀛戰神 2014 Ducati 899 Panigale 0-60 2.5
2012 Honda CB1000RR 2.6
ZX-14 2.6 and more from where that came from. I dont understand why you are 
bringing nitro bikes into this. Those ARE NOT stock bikes. Those are made 
to go to the drag strip.  Everybody knows a real race is settled on a race 
track. Where multiple times a bike has beat a supercar on a drag strip. 
Then car guys go so okay but no way will it win on a racetrack where the 
car can perform corners better. Then the bike goes out and wins.There has 
been times a car has beat the bike. If im going to watch drag racing its 
going to be NHRA where those cars were all built to go straight. Once again 
who cares about drag racing. When you buy a sport bike or a super car you 
are more likely to take it to a track then go to a drag strip. Simply 
because they were built for corners. Do you also know why cars are actually 
quicker around corners? Thats because of the contact patches. The car has 4 
big ones to the bikes 2 tiny one. Then the bike makes up for it on the 
straights. Proven time and time again. And just because something launches 
off the line faster does not mean its going to win the race. A 2010 
CBR1000RR did the 1/4 in  9.67 @ 150.3 mp/h . An 2006 R1 did it at 9.772 @ 
147.79 mp/h. SO could you please explain to me where you got your facts and 
how Bikes suck at drag strips?

comments.author: ANACCOUNTIDCATALL

comments.text:
+Philipp Widmann  It is a lot to do with gearing and the fact that the 
manufacturers gear the bikes to produce maximum speed a little before the 
speed limiter kicks in. The limiter activates in 6th gear. It works by 
sensing the gear and the speed signal from the final drive (countershaft). 
On the Hayabusa and other Suzuki models, the limiter works by retarding the 
timing on one cylinder thus capping the power output and any further 
increase in speed. That occurs at 299 kph or 186 mph indicated speed but 
the speedos are nearly always optimistic. You can see numerous Youtube 
videos that show stock superbikes reaching 299 kph on the speedo. On some 
other bike brands the revs seem to continue to rise but I don't know if 
that means the bike goes beyond the displayed speed. The 1999 Suzuki 
Hayabusa was unrestricted. It had 154 hp at the rear wheel. It was timed at 
317  kph (196 mph) to enter the Guinness BoR as the fastest production 
motorcycle. All subsequent Hayabusa's were restricted to 299 kph, although 
their power has increased with each new model. There were some early claims 
that the 1999 Hayabusa had been clocked at 323 kph (200 mph) but I don't 
know what conditions that was under (following breeze, cool etc) or if it 
were GPS recorded. there are many magazines that have tested the Hayabusa's 
top speed. 
The latest Hayabusa has 172 whp so it doesn't take a rocket scientist to 
understand that a derestricted 2014 Hayabusa with a slight change to the 
final drive ration could reach 200 mph under ideal conditions. I should 
point out that by changing the gear ratio and bypassing the speed 
restriction, means it is no longer absolutely stock.
comments.author: Robert Moore

comments.text:
+Mike Scott No, I'm pretty sure it has nothing to do with the gearing. But 
hey, I'm not a bike manufacturer, so don't quote me on that.
comments.author: Philipp Widmann

comments.text:
+Philipp Widmann Isn't the restriction enforced by gearing the production 
bike in such a way that when it hits the rev limiter in top, it's doing 
just under 300kph? In which case, a simple sprocket change is all that's 
required.
comments.author: Mike Scott

comments.text:
All or almost all bikes nowadays are electronically restricted to not go 
over 300kph because some countries have threatened to forbid the import of 
bikes with higher top speeds. Therefore the big companies agreed on 
restricting their bikes to 300kph. It's not a restriction in terms of 
power, just top speed.
comments.author: Philipp Widmann

comments.text:
What are you guys all talking about? The bike isn't restricted. It just 
needs a change to its gearing to reach 200mph. That's a quick and minor 
adjustment for a chain driven bike like the Panigale.

comments.text:

comments.author: Peter Joossen

comments.text:
+Jack Crowley 
Bikes are generally pretty terrible at braking - many modern family cars 
will stop as fast or faster from 60mph than even the best superbikes - its 
simple physics unfortunately, you just can't get much braking force down 
with such a small contact patch, and regardless of weight it becomes an 
issue of lack of available friction.

So the Porsche would slaughter the Ducati in out and out stopping power.

Then you have the issues of the difficulty of braking hard in real world 
conditions with a bike, which as mentioned earlier takes a lot of skill and 
a lot of balls - and if you mess it up you are going to lose control, and 
once you lose control, it's over.

Yes, I agree as soon as you get to high speeds, it's pretty moot, you're 
unlikely to survive an accident, even in the safest of cars.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
i seriously doubt that the Porsche stops faster then the panigale.  The

comments.text:
lol I take it that nobody in this process was aware that the bike was 
actually gear limited to 300km/h then?

Basically all big bikes have been capable of smashing 300 since the early 
2000's, some since the late 90's but bike manufacturers stopped chasing top 
speeds after the Hayabusa vs Super Blackbird thing more or less attracted 
regulators to the idea that bikes were "too fast"...

Put a different sprocket on the 1199 and watch the porsche get flogged 
above 300km/h as well if you're bored, otherwise, yeah... if your car will 
do above 300 then you can catch bikes once they've hit their legislator 
pleasing enforced top speed... you may as well argue that BMWs and Mercs 
are slow because they typically enforce the 250kn/h top speed limiting.﻿

get there it weights dry only 160 kg and produces more than 235 hp, 
according to official Ducati specs,but still he kept going on and on about

do not seem to understand how this stuff works, and sadly there is nothing

comments.text:
Also funny how these guys think their 180-190 hp bikes have the same top 
speed as a 260 hp, 320 lb MotoGP bike... LMAO...
comments.author: autopiacarcare

comments.text:
Duc, you are spot on. For a modern sportbike to eclipse 200 mph, it takes 
roughly 215 horsepower, give or take. This is, of course, highly dependent 
on aerodynamic efficiency and to a MUCH lesser degree weight (not 
accounting for proper gearing as well). Weight produces down force via 
gravity, which increases the frictional load on the tires (I'm sure you 
know this but these guys seem clueless). 

Bikes are aerodynamic bricks, relative to their size. While the frontal 
area is small, things like exposed tires, a flat radiator face, etc give 
them an aerodynamic profile similar to a 3x6 barn door. 

It's funny when the bullshitters, who have no education on such things and 
are painfully ignorant try to argue with people who have some knowledge 
base in the subject. They have gathered their information from the myths of 
other ignorant people and lack the knowledge to separate fact from fiction. 

I had a guy tell me his Gixxer 750 went 180. I showed him tests where it 
topped at about 167, I explained to him fluid dynamics and frictional 
losses. I even took the time to explain to him why motorcycle speedometers 
are nothing more than a rough estimate because the tire diameter shrinks 
considerably as the tire wears. He didn't care, his speedo, on his well 
worn and flattened tires, read 180 and he was convinced he was right... He 
couldn't even grasp the day, basic information to why he was wrong...

When people are confronted with logic and knowledge, they simply ignore 
what is over their head and go into sheeple mode. 

On a side note, why type of Duc do you ride? I have a 2013 TriColore and a 
2012 Diavel Carbon Red, as well as a beastly ZX10R track bike (that shits 
on Bimmers all day long).
comments.author: autopiacarcare

comments.text:
+NoneForYou I don't know if you replied to my comment or to someone 
else's...Anyway, as I already mentioned on my original post, and I 
explained the reasons 1 million times to some other guy, there is no 
PRODUCTION/STOCK bike on the planet that will reach more than 190-195 mph 
even without the limiter in place...And that my friend is due to bad 
aerodynamics all bikes have, in order to reach the 200 mph you mentioned a 
200 kg bike in order to overcome the drag will have to produce more than 
250 hp...And that's aeronautical engineering AND physics...
comments.author: 1DUCR

comments.text:
The 186 mph limit you are referring to is a manufacturer's agreed limit for 
public safety, nothing to do with physics. The governor is the reason the 
Porsche caught the bike. It had to hit 201 mph to catch the bike at it's 
limit which was 15 mph slower. Of course it would catch the bike at some 
point, that's not physics, that's common sense. Had the bike been 
unrestricted and going over 200 mph (as it would be), the Porsche never 
would have been able to catch up. Anything can be done in the aftermarket, 
give me a break. "Never" only means you can't do it.
